Steven Hollon of Vanderbilt University is one of the new study's co-authors.

There was a bit of a negative vibe for medications when the notion of publication bias came out, and this article, if anything, kind of evens up the playing field.

In both cases, there are enough good data there to tell us that those treatments work.
They're efficacious.
They're just not as efficacious as we think they probably are.
In both cases, the true efficacy is probably about a third less than we think it is.
Hollon says the published literature may have led psychiatrists and psychologists to be too optimistic about the depression treatments they offer.
